title: A hack to get 5% more leads
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-23, Reading time: 1 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fradoslawkaczynski_simple-hack-to-get-5-more-leads-add-email-activity-7349067050184511488-3Vvw%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/01000199763fafbe-3d21a26c-38b0-4234-87fb-ec0b5383ebaa-000000/2BnNvj4s-4Dc_10OIxaPZSWfxYWGeY-x9O07OwbeHbY=423
summary: A hack to get 5% more leads (1 minute read) Verify emails before form submission to prevent silent lead loss. Most missed leads come not from bounces but from mistyped addresses. This wastes ad spend, disrupts onboarding, creates support issues, and blocks re-engagement. One enterprise client discovered 5% of signups had typos, resulting in thousands of lost contacts and millions in potential LTV. Real-time verification keeps your funnel clean and conversion-ready.

title: Don't call your blog a blog

summary: Don't call your blog a blog (1 minute read) Avoid calling your blog a blog, as the term now suggests low-value content. Audiences are less interested in generic listicles and more drawn to unique data and insights relevant to their field.

title: I Wouldn't Hire a Content Engineer, and You Shouldn't Either

summary: I Wouldn't Hire a Content Engineer, and You Shouldn't Either (6 minute read) The “content engineer” role is misguided as scaled AI content delivers diminishing returns, faces search penalties, and is easily copied by competitors. The real opportunity lies in experimentation, originality, and quality, with AI serving as a creative partner. As AI fluency becomes a baseline skill for all marketers, a dedicated engineering role is unnecessary.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-23, Reading time: 13 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fbodadotsh%2Fnpm-security-best-practices%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199764252cf-50f04556-e1f3-4e73-9047-b5d887cb7ea0-000000/Wys4s2aqgY90KGh2Jzy0ApGHGJnTmlG7yIMHyxLklU0=423
summary: NPM Security Best Practices (13 minute read) This is a consolidated list of best practices for securing against incidents in the NPM ecosystem, covering npm, bun, deno, pnpm, and yarn. For devs, important best practices include pinning dependency versions, including lockfiles in repos, disabling lifecycle scripts, and reducing external dependencies. Maintainers should enable 2FA, create tokens with limited access, generate provenance statements, and always review published files.

title: Dear GitHub: no YAML anchors, please
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-23, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.yossarian.net%2F2025%2F09%2F22%2Fdear-github-no-yaml-anchors%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199764252cf-50f04556-e1f3-4e73-9047-b5d887cb7ea0-000000/5VmGXdS2NWiIoXd_QIcGxlAIEBG-zzCNiUpO3-UwZuY=423
summary: Dear GitHub: no YAML anchors, please (9 minute read) This dev isn't a fan of GitHub's recent addition of YAML anchor support to GitHub Actions. YAML anchors are redundant, complicate workflow comprehension for both humans and machines, and don't have any unique utility due to the absence of merge key support in GitHub Actions. This change makes it harder to analyze workflows for vulnerabilities, thereby worsening GitHub Actions' security.

title: Cap'n Web: a new RPC system for browsers and web servers
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-23, Reading time: 21 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.cloudflare.com%2Fcapnweb-javascript-rpc-library%2F%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199764252cf-50f04556-e1f3-4e73-9047-b5d887cb7ea0-000000/eF_RFW0IvL0lfbHJAmx9xOcneGExYFOLZDQ9Bgnv8JU=423
summary: Cap'n Web: a new RPC system for browsers and web servers (21 minute read) Cap'n Web is a new, open-source RPC system for JavaScript environments for facilitating communication between applications over a network. Unlike traditional RPC, Cap'n Web supports bidirectional calling, object-capability security, and promise pipelining, aiming for a developer experience similar to native JavaScript APIs. It makes setup easier, integrates with TypeScript, and uses human-readable JSON serialization.

title: Why Local-First Apps Haven't Become Popular?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-23, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmarcobambini.substack.com%2Fp%2Fwhy-local-first-apps-havent-become%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199764252cf-50f04556-e1f3-4e73-9047-b5d887cb7ea0-000000/PGb_c3b_jqqfnTufBg_c41DhUf4JbY_R-Yb0gA8FTMY=423
summary: Why Local-First Apps Haven't Become Popular? (6 minute read) Local-first apps have adoption challenges due to the complexity of syncing data across devices, especially offline. The key to successful local-first apps lies in achieving eventual consistency, making sure all devices converge to the same state without data loss. This happens through techniques like Hybrid Logical Clocks (HLCs) for reliable ordering and Conflict-Free Replicated Data Types (CRDTs) to handle data conflicts.

title: AI-Generated “Workslop” Is Destroying Productivity
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-23, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhbr.org%2F2025%2F09%2Fai-generated-workslop-is-destroying-productivity%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199764252cf-50f04556-e1f3-4e73-9047-b5d887cb7ea0-000000/5kNLrdw7TzqqeCDpfayVGF3fpHmPZELEkG596Oo-KPU=423
summary: AI-Generated “Workslop” Is Destroying Productivity (11 minute read) "Workslop" is AI-generated content that lacks substance but appears polished. Due to AI being used more, there's more low-effort AI slop at work, leading to worse productivity overall, as it shifts the burden of real effort to the receivers of the AI slop. This "workslop tax" has financial and interpersonal costs, bringing down trust and collaboration.

summary: The Right Size Project (7 minute read) Freelancers and small agencies should focus on "right-sized" projects rather than chasing big jobs they're not ready for. Success comes from starting with smaller projects where you can guarantee outsized results, then gradually scaling up as you build proof and confidence in delivering larger value.

summary: Why Continuous Profiling is the Fourth Pillar of Observability (8 minute read) Early profilers focused mainly on CPU and needed manually compiled binaries, which caused high performance overhead. Industry leaders are pushing for alignment with GDPR's risk-based model, while privacy groups raise concerns that data protections could be weakened.

summary: Getting AI to Work in Complex Codebases (20 minute read) With core context engineering principles and frequent intentional compaction, current AI models can be great at handling large, detailed codebases. AI can rarely produce correct code in one shot in large code bases, so it needs steps before implementation to do research on the codebase and plan its steps.

title: Thundering Herd Problem: Preventing the Stampede

summary: Thundering Herd Problem: Preventing the Stampede (8 minute read) The "thundering herd" problem occurs when a cache miss leads to a large number of concurrent requests hitting the database for the same record, overwhelming it. title: Tired of cookie consent pop-ups? You soon may see less of them
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-24, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmashable.com%2Farticle%2Fcookie-consent-pop-ups-eu-looking-to-change-law%3Futm_source=tldrdesign/1/010001997b9dfb91-bb019b76-fcf6-4ad7-b33b-416ccad33561-000000/-xDTwsJchdIuftxzMBz6z5pNX5RCPVxdzbF5cRQQ0jM=424
summary: Tired of cookie consent pop-ups? You soon may see less of them (2 minute read) The EU is reviewing its 2009 e-Privacy Directive, which created the widespread cookie consent pop-ups, and may relax the rules to reduce user frustration. Possible changes include adding more exceptions or letting users set consent in their browser. Privacy advocates warn this could weaken protections and expand data use for advertising.

title: How to Spot Signs of UX Maturity Regression
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-24, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.nngroup.com%2Farticles%2Fsigns-of-ux-maturity-regression%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdesign/1/010001997b9dfb91-bb019b76-fcf6-4ad7-b33b-416ccad33561-000000/QazlRAsVv7o5EmV2fss5gnz-aakq5aIEuvtvj1GLN4c=424
summary: How to Spot Signs of UX Maturity Regression (8 minute read) The UX-maturity model outlines how organizations progress in UX across strategy, culture, process, and outcomes. Maturity can regress if practices stagnate, leadership changes, or UX becomes siloed. Teams can prevent drift by watching for early signals, keeping lightweight check-ins, broadening ownership beyond UX, and integrating maturity into ongoing business processes to maintain momentum.

title: VCBench: Benchmarking LLMs in Venture Capital
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-24, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Farxiv.org%2Fpdf%2F2509.14448%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/010001997b9f218e-7c54b49c-bb92-415e-be0a-d882e035f3eb-000000/2v9OlXt15U22A6HIpzLXKD-UME_Kn96_bEXHYuV4jNo=424
summary: VCBench: Benchmarking LLMs in Venture Capital (9 minute read) Startup investing has long been guesswork, with even top VCs picking winners less than 6% of the time. VCBench is trying to change that: a dataset of 9,000 anonymized founder profiles built to test whether models can predict success better than humans. After scrubbing names, dates, and company info to prevent leakage, researchers ran nine LLMs. GPT-4o delivered 3.2× baseline precision, edging past tier-1 firms.

summary: Sampling and structured outputs in LLMs (10 minute read) Sampling is the process of selecting a token from a model's vocabulary based on the probability distribution. Structured outputs allow models to turn unstructured data into structured data. Together, they both determine a model's next chosen token. Large language models are extremely sensitive to the slightest variation in their system prompts, templating, structured outputs, and sampling parameters.

title: Orchestrating Data Quality with Airflow
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-25, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.astronomer.io%2Fblog%2Forchestrating-data-quality-with-airflow%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019980574e3a-42991f65-26a7-4adf-b838-8256c8168427-000000/cqAhcDbm0rvzALrq-TsrJISL3y8x7r5sVQB2RI_yi3U=424
summary: Orchestrating Data Quality with Airflow (7 minute read) Maintaining high data quality is challenging due to unclear ownership, bugs, messy source data, and constant changes. By utilizing reusable task groups, data engineers can embed quality checks directly into their workflows, promoting a proactive approach to maintaining data trust and reliability.

summary: Bytewax (GitHub Repo) Bytewax is a Python-native, stateful stream processing framework with a Rust-based engine designed to build real-time data pipelines and applications. It supports scalable deployments, manages state automatically, and offers a flexible API for operations like map, filter, join, and windowing while integrating seamlessly with Python libraries and data sources like Kafka and filesystems.

summary: Postgres' Original Project Goals: The Creators Totally Nailed It (9 minute read) Postgres was designed in the 1980s with goals like handling complex data, being extensible, supporting triggers, simplifying recovery, using new hardware, and staying true to the relational model. title: Why you should replace PostgreSQL with Git for your next project
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-25, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdevcenter.upsun.com%2Fposts%2Fwhy-you-should-replace-postgresql-with-git-for-your-next-project%2F%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199809c3ebf-359a83f3-0db3-499f-9ae2-38b1d1dbff9f-000000/SYBUYXlkskaBWphszsGl0aqFbaiUv7WZWnZK3loZs2M=424
summary: Why you should replace PostgreSQL with Git for your next project (5 minute read) Git can technically be used as a database, though it's not recommended. Git inherently provides versioning, concurrency handling, atomic transactions, and fast data retrieval through its object model of blobs, trees, commits, and references. This article goes over a simple todo application that uses Git's command-line tools, showing how to store and organize data.

title: Redis is fast - I'll cache in Postgres
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-25, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdizzy.zone%2F2025%2F09%2F24%2FRedis-is-fast-Ill-cache-in-Postgres%2F%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199809c3ebf-359a83f3-0db3-499f-9ae2-38b1d1dbff9f-000000/RCKdyPsHPcZDgkcvtwp8RhVQyS4HL3xbgvuBip8HRSE=424
summary: Redis is fast - I'll cache in Postgres (8 minute read) Redis and Postgres are compared as caching solutions by building a simple HTTP server and benchmarking read, write, and mixed workloads on a Kubernetes cluster. Redis consistently outperformed Postgres in terms of requests per second and latency, even with Postgres using unlogged tables for faster writes. The bottleneck for Redis was often the HTTP server's CPU, while Postgres frequently maxed out its allocated CPU resources.

summary: Queues, Buses, and Streams (6 minute read) AWS messaging services can be grouped into queues, buses, and streams, each optimized for different patterns of data movement.
